bibl.title: Correspondance littéraire
bibl.editor: Friedrich Melchior Grimm and Jacques-Henri Meister
bibl.note: Biweekly manuscript cultural newsletter, edited by Grimm until 1773 and then by Meister. It small circulation of about 16 crowned heads of Europe included Catherine the Great, Frederick II, and Stanislas Poniatowski. Denis Diderot's 'Salons' were first circulated in its pages. The last complete edition is Correspondance littéraire, philosophique et critique, par Grimm, Diderot, Raynal, Meister, Etc., ed. by Maurice Tourneux, 16 vols (Paris: Garnier Frères, 1877-1882). A new critical edition is underway, under the editorship of Ulla Kölving at the Centre international d'étude du XVIIIe siècle.
bibl.bibl: Grimm, Friedrich M., Denis Didero, and Jacques-Henri Meister, Correspondance littéraire (1753-90). <https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5720289p.texteImage > [accessed 30 November 2021]

bibl.title: Opera komicheskaya, Gorebogatyr Kosometovich
The Woe-Ridden Knight Kosometovich, a comic opera
bibl.author: Catherine the Great
bibl.note: Comic opera that Catherine composed first as a fairytale ('Skazka o Gorebogatyre Kosometoviche') to mock Gustav III of Sweden during the Russo-Swedish War. (Kosometovich means 'he who throws crookedly'.) Although it was performed at Catherine's Hermitage Theatre, Potemkin convinced her not to have it performed on the public stage, since that would have been an excessive affront to her fellow ruler. The composer was Vincente Martín y Soler. Published in Pypin, Sochineniya imperatritsy Ekateriny II, ii, pp. 483-520.
bibl.bibl: Catherine the Great, Opera komicheskaia, Gorebogatyr' Kosometovich (1788).

bibl.title: Das Graue Ungeheuer
bibl.note: In a letter to Friedrich Melchior Grimm of 14 August 1788, Catherine commented with heavy irony on an 'purported portrait' of her in this journal: the writer ranked Catherine just under Maria Theresa of Austria, praised her by saying she did not do all sorts of horrible things, and called her 'mehr schlau als verständig oder witzig' ('more sly than prudent or witty'). (SIRIO, xxiii, p. 462.)
bibl.bibl: Das Graue Ungeheuer (Nürnberg, January 1784-December 1787).

bibl.title: La Henriade
bibl.author: Voltaire
bibl.note: See the critical edition by O.R. Taylor in the Œuvres complètes de Voltaire, volume 2. An earlier version of 'La Henriade' appeared in 1723 as 'La Ligue'. Often reprinted throughout the century, enjoyed immense esteem and as his most successful epic poem brought Voltaire the prestige of comparison with the likes of Virgil (and initially attracted the patronage of the future Frederick II, then Crown Prince of Prussia).

bibl.title: De la monarchie prussienne sous Frédéric le Grand
bibl.author: Honoré Gabriel Riqueti, comte de Mirabeau
bibl.note: Catherine was probably most offended by Mirabeau's comments about Russia volume 4, part 2: 'La Russie fait mal la guerre: ses généraux, ses officiers sont d'une ignorance extrême; ses campagnes contre les Ottomans n'ont été, des deux côtés, qu'une suite de fautes plus folles les unes que les autres. Mais cette guerre, jointe à l'incomparable bravoure des soldats russes, qui leur a fait remporter plusieurs fois des victoires sur les excellentes troupes de Frédéric II, a donné à la Russie une considération très-dangereuse' ('Russia wages war poorly: their generals and officers are extremely ignorant; their campaigns against the Ottomans were, on both sides, merely a sequence of mistakes, one madder than the next. But that war, combined with the incomparable bravery of the Russian soldiery, which afforded them several victories over Frederick II's excellent troops, has given Russia a very dangerous level of consideration', page 322); and, particularly, speaking of Austria's possible alliances, 'La plus dangereuse de toutes, c'est celle de la Russie avec l'Autriche; et malheureusement la haute conception de la czarine de renouveler l'empire d'orient, en chassant les Turcs d'Europe, cette idée ambitieuse, et tôt ou tard destructive de l'empire russe, tel du moins que nous le connoissons aujourd'hui, mais qui n'en bouleversera pas moins l'Europe par son explosion; cette idée devenue passion, et que l'empereur paroit entretenir et flatter avec beaucoup d'adresse, en a vraisemblablement amené l'époque' ('The most dangerous of all is that of Russia with Austria, and unfortunately the czarina's lofty notion of renewing the Eastern Empire and chasing the Turks from Europe. This ambitious idea, which will sooner or later destroy the Russian Empire at least in the form we know it today, will nonetheless shake Europe when it explodes. This idea, which has become a passion and which the emperor seems to entertain and flatter with much skill, has probably brought about the time at which this will come to pass', pp. 329-30).
bibl.bibl: Riqueti, Honoré Gabriel, De la monarchie prussienne sous Frédéric le Grand (Londres [Paris?]: , 1788). <https://www.rct.uk/collection/1025584/de-la-monarchie-prussienne-sous-frederic-le-grand-t-5-comte-de-mirabeau> [accessed 30 November 2021]

bibl.title: Nakaz kommissii o sostavlenii proekta novago ulozheniya
Instruction to the Commission for the Composition of a Project of a New Law Code
Наказ Коммиссии о составлении проекта новаго уложения
bibl.author: Catherine the Great
bibl.note: Catherine composed this instruction to guide the consultative commission of representatives from all ranks of free subjects and from all regions of the Russian Empire, whom she called together in Moscow in 1767 to discuss plans for a new legal code. The last Russian legal code was promulgated in 1648-49. Catherine borrowed heavily from Montesquieu's 'L'Esprit des lois' and Cesare Beccaria's 'On Crimes and Punishments', adapting these works of Enlightenment political philosophy to Russia. The Nakaz was read aloud to the Commission twice and first printed in Russian in 1767 (a scanned copy of this edition can be seen here). The usual scholarly text in Russian is the 1907 edition by N.D. Chechulin. A scholary English edition is: Paul Dukes, 2 vols, 'Russia under Catherine the Great', ii: 'Catherine the Great's Instruction (Nakaz) to the Legislative Commission, 1767' (Newtonville, MA: Oriental Research Partners, 1977).
bibl.bibl: Catherine the Great, Nakaz kommissii o sostavlenii proekta novago ulozheniia (Moscow: Senat, 1767). <https://www.prlib.ru/item/428545> [accessed 30 November 2021]

bibl.title: Polnoe sobranie vsekh do nyne perevedennykh na Rossiiskii yazyk i v pechat izdannykh sochinenii g. Voltera
Полное собрание всех до ныне переведенных на Российский язык и в печать изданных сочинений г. Вольтера
bibl.author: Voltaire
bibl.note: I.G. Rakhmaninov had begun translating Voltaire in 1777 (three philosophical dialogues under the title 'Три разговора их Волтеровых сочинений', or 'Three Conversations from Voltaire's Works'), and in 1785-89 he published the first 'collected works' of Voltaire in Russian ('Sobranie sochinenii g. Voltera', in three volumes). In 1788, he set up his own printing press on his estate at Kazinka, Tambov Province, for the purpose of publishing his own and others' translations of Voltaire in 20 parts. The edition began appearing in 1791. Only three volumes were published, a fourth was ready to be sold, and a fifth had been typeset when, in 1793, the Procurator-General of the Holy Synod, A.N. Samoilov, at Catherine's behest, ordered that Rakhmaninov's press be shut down and the books confiscated. An effort was made in the early nineteenth century to revive Rakhmaninov's edition: the two banned volumes, five more volumes of prose works, and a three-volume 'Spirit, or selected philosophical thoughts of Mr. Voltaire' ('Дух, или избранные философические мысли г. Вольтера') appeared, but almost the entire edition of the latter was destroyed in the Moscow fire of 1812. (P.R. Zaborov, Russkaya literatura i Volter, pp. 74-78; P.R. Zaborov, 'Volter v russkoi pechati XVIII-XX vekov', in Volter v Rossii, pp. 5-9 (p. 6).)
bibl.bibl: Voltaire, Polnoe sobranie vsekh do nyne perevedennykh na Rossiiskii iazyk i v pechat' izdannykh sochinenii g. Voltera, 4 vols (Kazinka, Tambov Province, 1791-1812).

bibl.title: Zapiski kasatelno rossiiskoi istorii
bibl.author: Catherine the Great
bibl.note: First published in Sobesednik lyubitelei rossiiskago slova, 1783-84. Part 4 was expanded when the text was republished in 1787. Continuations appeared in 1793 (Part 5) and 1794 (Part 6).
